intro: Orobanche fissa, commonly known as the narrow-leaved broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is found in various regions of Europe and Asia. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are often white or pink in color. Its life cycle involves germinating alongside its host and establishing a connection through specialized roots called haustoria. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly impact the growth and health of its host plants.
